Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Sustainable Grid Integration of Distributed and Renewable Resources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports a research and educational program at The University of Texas at Austin to address sustainable grid integration of distributed and renewable energy systems, a crucial priority for greenhouse gas reduction and energy independence. A key context for this project is The Pecan Street Project, a collaborative university-utility Austin-based effort to redesign and reformulate Austin's electric power system. The research goal is to revolutionize the way energy is produced, used, stored, and traded consistent with economic, environment, social, and security objectives. Results will be applicable to distributed power (smart grid) systems throughout the U.S. and will have a significant economic impact.

Trainees will be engaged in collaborative basic and applied research in data communications, cybersecurity, network management computation, distributed generation (solar, wind, fuel cells), power electronics and controls, energy storage (batteries, flywheels, compressed air, thermal storage, electric vehicles), building HVAC systems and energy efficient buildings, efficient appliances, and sensors for system performance, tracking, and optimization. IGERT trainees will develop course materials appropriate for high school math and science educators in support of UTeachEngineering, and will assist in the creation of content for a graduate-level course on the Grid Of The Future. Outreach to underrepresented groups in K-12 will be facilitated by UTeachEngineering and development of new educational materials for high school engineering courses.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of a university collaborative inter-intra-departmental undertaking became a reality in spring of 2010 with the launch of IGERT: Sustainable Grid Integration of Distributed and Renewable Resources located at The University of Texas at Austin. A natural environment for scaffolding affiliations, networks, and research developed from the complex partnerships inspired by IGERT between UT and Pecan Street Inc. with participation from 20 faculty members from schools of Architecture, Engineering, Natural Sciences, Business, Law, and LBJ School emerged as the grant evolved. The exchange of students and research between TU Munchen and the Netherlands added international components that proved advantageous to all students involved.

The first year of IGERT met challenges that included inter-university participation coupled with graduate students who did not know each other or their colleagues’ research pressed into a collaborative setting. Year one resulted in a very lose coupling of the IGERT cohort. However, changes made in management of the IGERT weekly meetings, recommendations from the Advisory Committee, students working on a single project together under the direction of Dr. Thomas Edgar, and interspersing social activities transformed the IGERT program. The momentum generated from these changes resulted in an organic organization and group of researchers who established a reputation for their group – IGERT, and generated respect from other researchers in multiple research areas of sustainable resources and energy.

Following the next five years, IGERT became a brand that signified progressive inquiry in a variety of areas that led to important spheres of influence in public policy and research. Our IGERT alumni are now among experts in areas of sustainable grid integration and renewable resources’ research. The IGERT alumni are sought-after candidates for university professors, leaders in university forums and other research collaboratives associated with their research agendas to include topics on water and wind energy, Eagle Ford Shale drilling, electric vehicles and the smart grid. Some of the graduate students have continued their research as post-docs in areas that will extend their research findings beyond their dissertation topics and ultimately to patents as well as continue the spirit of the IGERT vision of supporting renewable energy for many years in the future. The IGERT legacy continues with the alternative course offerings and modified schedules at The University of Texas at Austin.

The IGERT participants heavily influenced the system of traditional semester course offerings. Prior to the IGERT program, alternative schedules of course offerings was limited. However, with the implementation of IGERT and the students’ exposure to a variety of closely connected research agendas, students insisted that they wanted more classes but in a condensed format. The weekly meetings exposed students to their peer’s research. Quickly, students made associations between their research and the other students with their research presentations. One student stated, “I am so interested in water and I know it will help my research but my class schedule is so tight, I can’t find a way to take a class.” The Advisory committee also recommended more class offerings in an alternative format. Thus, beginning in 2012, a three-day short-course “Introduction to Electric Power for Legal, Accounting, and Regulatory Professionals” and a one-day short-course “Locational Marginal Pricing” for non-technical professionals in the electricity industry was introduced followed by new courses that include: Technology Commercialization, Energy Development and Policy, Advanced Topics in Power Electronics,  Modern Control Theory, Clean.Smart.Energy, Water Technology and Policy, and Energy Technology and Policy. The short courses are very popular and continue to be in demand. A graduate portfolio program in Energy Studies (GPPES) has also been added at UT as a result of IGERT. The GPPES signifies an authentic response to mounting university-wide student interest in sustainable energy studies introduced by the IGERT program implemented in 2010 and supported by the UT Austin Energy Institute. The complexity of offering a multi-departmental program is counterbalanced by permitting students to design their own program to meet the coursework requirements of the GPPES by choosing from a wide range of courses offered by participating departments. Completion of the GPPES facilitates students’ interests in energy policy issues and enables students across the university to demonstrate to future employers through their final transcripts the students’ credentials in the field of energy. 

The IGERT program has produced a permanent and enduring legacy. As IGERT students graduate and enter professorships, research groups such as NREL, SANDIA, and Argonne National Labs, assume leadership roles as authors for Scientific American and editors for contemporary research journals, and respond to invitations to address national and international audiences on topics pertaining to sustainable and renewable resources, IGERT remains alive and well. Isaac Newton stated, “If I have seen further it is standing on the shoulders of Giants” [The Correspondence of Isaac Newton] and the IGERT alumni have become the giants for future researchers to stand on their shoulders.
